p: Throughout the twentieth century and continuing today, the Mississippi Delta (“the Delta,” composed predominantly of the Delta regions of Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Tennessee, but also including the adjacent “boot-heel” of Missouri) and the areas of the former Cotton Belt in the American South, have remained among the poorest regions in the nation ( Figure 1) [11]. High rural poverty rates, inadequate housing, and poor health are the hallmarks of poverty in the Delta and adjacent regions [11], [36]. More than one-half of the population is black [37], and over one-third of the total Delta black population lives in poverty, as does almost one-half of the rural black Delta population [11]. Overall, 5.8 million people live in America 7, the poor blacks of the rural American South [14].
